title-group.article-title: Microlevel manufacturing process simulation of carbon fiber/epoxy composites to analyze the effect of chemical and thermal induced residual stresses

article-meta.aff: Faserinstitut Bremen e.V., Am Biologischen Garten 2, Bremen, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Christian Brauner, Faserinstitut Bremen e.V., Am Biologischen Garten 2, 28359 Bremen, Germany Email: brauner@faserinstitut.de

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A micromechanical implicit finite element analysis using Samcef/Mecano was performed to analyze the effect of process-induced deformations and stresses on a unidirectional carbon fiber–epoxy composite material (G1157/RTM6). During the manufacturing process, chemical and thermal shrinkage deformations occur and lead to internal stresses. In this article, several effects on the level of stress on the microscale will be discussed, which address the nonlinear behavior of the polymer matrix material. A parametric study was done on the influence of these effects on residual stresses including temperature dependency of the young’s modulus, thermal expansion coefficient, nonlinear thermomechanical stress–strain behavior, microyielding, microdegradation, and viscoelasticity. Several experiments have been carried out to investigate the thermomechanical behavior of the matrix material and to derivate constitutive equations. The derived equations and the discussed effects are integrated into an analysis model of a squared unit cell and used to perform a coupled curing thermomechanical simulation. As a result, the development of process-induced stresses is presented with the integration of nonlinear local material effects. Assessment of these effects is one of the key aspects for interpretation of process-induced stresses on the macroscale.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
High-performance carbon fiber-reinforced composite materials are widely used in aerospace structures due to their many advantages compared to conventional metallic materials. The distinctive feature of these composite materials is that resulting material properties can be designed by selection of different fiber/fabric and matrix materials and are influenced by the manufacturing process itself. As matrix material epoxy resin as a thermoset polymer is mostly used and due to the high requirements of the aerospace industries toughened, thermally stable resin systems are preferred. This leads to the point that typically resin systems are chosen with a high curing temperature around 180°C to reach glass transition temperatures above 160°C. During the curing of carbon fibre reinforced plastics (CFRP) materials, inhomogeneous material properties play a major role in the development of process-induced deformations and stresses due to the effect of chemical matrix shrinkage and thermal expansion. The resulting material properties will be influenced by process-dependent deformations and stresses. In fact, internal stresses may become large enough to lead to fiber matrix debonding, matrix failure, or delamination. In general, defects on the microscale like matrix fiber debonding or small matrix cracks are hardly measurable and therefore only noticeable in reduced stiffness or strength properties (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Influence of process defects on the material strength.1

The superposition of process-induced and mechanical stresses also leads to critical situations. In composite materials, residual stresses can change the failure behavior.1 Using criteria like the Puck criterion, a complex stress state can be condensed and displayed by a vector of effort. In general, this vector starts at the origin of the material coordinate system and indicates failure, if it touches the engulfing failure curve. In case of present residual stresses, the vector of effort does not start at the origin anymore (Figure 2). By neglecting process-dependent stresses, the effort value can change significantly, for example, the mode of transverse failure can change from mode B to the more critical failure mode C. Figure 2.
Influence of residual stress on the failure behavior.1 Left side (a) without residual stress, right side (b) change of the material effort due to residual stress.
This highlights the need of reliable methods to analyze the level of process-dependent residual stresses

In the last decades, many researchers investigated the development of process-induced stresses on a macromechanical level2,3,4–7 and also on the microscopic level. The validation of process-induced stresses on the macrolevel is very difficult, in fact there are no nondestructive or destructive validated tests available to measure stress in composites. The development of process-induced deformations is mostly understood and has been modeled,2,3,7 but stresses are influenced by nonlinear effects like viscoelasticity, microscopic yielding and degradation, temperature, and cure-dependent engineering constants. The question of choosing micro or macro approaches can be addressed to the physical effects which occur. Hobbiebrunken et al.8 has shown that thermoset resins behave thermomechanically complex and effects like microyielding and microdegradation dependent on the temperature will affect the maximum microscopic stress level significantly.8 Therefore an analysis of the development of residual stresses on the micromechanical level can be an important tool to interpret effects and verify homogenized residual stresses on the macrolevel.

In the literature, two general approaches can be found on the issue of fiber and matrix distribution inside composites. The first approach assumes a regular geometric distribution of fiber and matrix by squared or hexagonal unit cells, the second considers larger unit cells of random fiber arrays. The first approach has the advantage that many researchers have already developed analytical solutions. For example, Puck6 has published a method to calculate the strain magnification of the matrix by applying external loads. These approaches might not represent the real topology of the structure but using geometrical simplifications, such as a unit cell, efficient analytical micromechanic equations can be derived. Therefore, a regular geometric distribution will be chosen in this study.

This work attempts to investigate the effect of combined chemical and thermal strains using a coupled curing and mechanical simulation. Therefore a cure kinetic approach is implemented into a transient implicit finite element analysis via a user subroutine. Using this approach, the curing of the resin is simulated and linked to the development of the engineering constants, curing strains, and changes in the thermal expansion coefficient. The presented article focuses on nonlinear effects in the resin due to temperature. Experiments are performed to characterize the influence of the temperature on the Young’s modulus, the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE), relaxation effects, and also on the stress–strain relation, in order to identify microyielding and microdegradation. In the second part, these effects are integrated stepwise into a finite element model and investigated.

sec.title: Material characterization
sec.p: This chapter addresses the characterization of the thermomechanical behavior of resin subjected to the curing reaction and temperature. Key aspects are the development of the resin modulus dependant on the degree of cure, the temperature dependency of the resin modulus, the dependency of the thermal expansion coefficient on the degree of cure and the temperature, the total amount of resin shrinkage, and the thermomechanical behavior (nonlinear temperature-dependent stress–strain behavior). The chapter is structured in the way that the single physical quantities are separately analyzed. Characterization of the single key aspects ends up with constitutive equations and parameters for the numerical analysis. A unidirectional composite consisting of the C-Fibre TENAX HTA 5131 and the premixed epoxy resin HEXCEL RTM6 was taken as example material.
The carbon fiber properties are based on a product of Tenax Fibers which are, for example, part of G1157 D 1300 Injectex fabric. The type of fiber is part of the high tenacity class.6

The presented study concentrates on a polyfunctional epoxy resin, RTM6, supplied by Hexcel Composites (UK). The resin, intended for the manufacturing of aircraft composite structures using the resin transfer molding (RTM) process, is currently receiving considerable attention from civil aircraft manufacturers. The expected service temperatures of final products range from −60°C to 180°C. The uncured resin has a density of 1.117 g/cm3 and the fully cured resin 1.141 g/cm3. The recommended cure regime for this resin is 160°C for 75 min, followed by a postcure at 180°C for 2 h, resulting in an expected glass transition temperature of about 183°C in the cured material. Alternatively, five different cure cycles are possible and approved by the supplier. In this study, all specimens are manufactured using cycle 5. Therefore the recommended curing temperature of 180°C for 120 min will result in a glass transition temperature of 196 and a final degree of cure around 96%. Table 2 shows the resin properties given for the cured material.9 Table 1.
Fiber properties6
Young’s modulus in fiber direction Ef1 = 210,000 N/mm2
Young’s modulus transverse Ef2 = 28,240 N/mm2
Shear modulus Gf = 50,600 N/mm2
Poisson’s ratio υf12 = 0.225
CTE in fiber direction αf1 = −0.045 × 10−6 1/K
CTE transverse to the fiber direction αf2 = 12.5 × 10−6 1/K
Strength in fiber direction Rf = 3430 N/mm2
Fiber diameter df = 7 µm
CTE: coefficient of thermal expansion.
Table 2.
Matrix properties (cured)
Young’s modulus Em = 2890 N/mm2
Shear modulus Gm = 1070 N/mm2
Poisson’s ratio υm = 0.35
CTE αm = 65 × 10−6 1/K
Strength Rm = 75 N/mm2
CTE: coefficient of thermal expansion.

sec.title: Cure kinetics
sec.p: The description of the curing process of thermoset resin, which transforms from the liquid into the solid state at an elevated temperature, can be described using generalized empirical rate equations or mechanistic models. Mechanistic models start to describe the curing process from an atomistic scale by descriptions of the growing macromolecules. The empirical rate approach derivates a phenomenological mathematical description of the curing process by experimental studies using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). Using this method, the exothermic heat flow is measured and interpreted taking the assumption that this heat flow is proportional to the degree of cure. The reaction kinetics are typically used to describe a reaction of nth order with p representing the conversion factor (varying from 1 to 0) also known as the degree of cure. The function p describes the development of the degree of cure. The temperature dependency is described by the Arrhenius rate constant ki: (1)

The Arrhenius term is based on material and process parameters with the thermal activation energy of the reaction Si, the universal gas constant R, and the temperature T. The variation of kinetic reaction models available in the literature for different resin systems is manifold. In general, the model must be able to handle different cure situations especially taking into account the variation of isothermal and dynamic temperature conditions.
Kamal and Sourour developed the following model which is mostly used for the given resin system in the literature:10 (2)dpdt=(k1+k2·pm)(pmax-p)n.

As shown in Figure 3, the development of the degree of cure using the approach of Kamal/Sourour agrees with experimental measurements in a temperature range of 160–180°C. Figure 3.
Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) results and analytical fit of different isothermal curing conditions.

Ryan and Dutta7 extended the model and varied the variables m and n depending on the temperature. This might help to increase accuracy of the approach, but in this study, the simple approach is used as the values for the curing temperature of 180°C are sufficient.

sec.title: Shrinkage of resin during the curing process
sec.p: The chemically induced volumetric shrinkage is directly related to the degree of cure and one of the main reasons for residual stresses. Therefore the total amount of chemical shrinkage and the cure-related behavior is important in order to understand the development of residual stresses. In general, two approaches are available to determine shrinkage: volume dilatometry, here the change of a dimension is measured, and nonvolume dilatometric methods, here the shrinkage is derived by equivalent variables, for example, warpage of a two-layer plate, force, strain of optical sensors, and so on. It can be concluded that these two different approaches lead to different results related to the fact that nonvolume dilatometry is problematic in that contact between resin and a solid surface (mold) can induce stresses. Therefore different statements can be found in the literature about the dependency of chemical shrinkage on the degree of cure. Holst defines a linear dependency (volumetric approach), while Liu constitute bilinear behavior (nonvolumetric approach).11,12

Using a thermomechanical analyzer (TMA) setup, a simple test has been performed. Encapsulated DSC pans have been filled with resin and placed inside the TMA compression test setup. Applying a small preload force, the deformation of the cap during isothermal curing conditions at 150°C has been observed. The results gained using the analytical approach of Kamal/Sourour are plotted vs. the degree of cure in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Resin shrinkage against degree of cure, measured using thermomechanical analyzer (TMA) setup.

The result of this experiment might be that sources of error like friction between the cap and the pan, overflow of the resin, and the preload force have a considerable influence. This can be observed in the large variation of the measurement values. Nevertheless, a clear trend is visible that the shrinkage of the resin can be idealized as linear function on the degree of cure. The total amount of chemical shrinkage Vsh was around 4.8%.

Using this result, shrinkage can be introduced into the analysis using an incremental strain formulation for isotropic materials. The total volumetric shrinkage Vsh has to be multiplied with the increment of the degree of cure. (3)dV=Vsh·dp (4)dɛsh=(1-dV)13-1.
This chemical shrinkage strain increment can be used to calculate the total strain increment: (5)dɛge=dɛel+dɛth+dɛsh.

sec.title: Mechanical behavior of resin during the curing process
sec.p: The constitutive model of the resin has to represent the mechanical behavior at the different stages of the curing process. It is useful to divide the development of the resin properties into three separate phases: first, a phase of purely viscous behavior, where the resin does not support shear loads and does not develop residual stresses; second, a phase of viscoelastic behavior after gelation (gel point), where stresses will be generated, but decay to some degree relative to the process time; and third, a phase of elastic behavior after vitrification, where the material behaves nearly linearly. A material model must take into account all three stages. Different approaches have been developed in the last decades starting to couple the resin modulus directly to the degree of cure.10 Further approaches can be found in the literature on the aspect of how to model the resin modulus development by either linear, incremental linear,3 or nonlinear approaches.11–13 Therefore an important objective question will be about classification of the resin development vs. degree of cure. To answer this question, shear rheological measurements have been performed using a plate-to-plate method with a frequency of 1 Hz and an amplitude of 0.1% strain. Four test cases are investigated for isothermal conditions at temperatures 120, 150, 180, and 200°C. For determination of the gel point, the intersection of the storage modulus and the loss modulus has been used. The point of vitrification is evaluated by fulfillment of a nonchange criterion of the storage modulus over time.

As a first result, the storage modulus curves against time can be classified in the way that the development of the resin modulus for slow curing processes at low temperatures represents a nonlinear behavior. In case of a fast reaction at high temperatures, the development seems linear. If the experimental curves are plotted against the degree of cure this has to be rectified. In all four cases, the resin modulus development must be represented at least by an incremental approach,3 which takes into account the gel point and the point of vitrification. Using the shear rheometer experiments, the development of the resin during cure was observed at an isothermal curing temperature of 150°C. The development of the resin modulus can be idealized by the following function: (6)T**=1(1-Tg-TgelT-Tgel) (7)G=[1(1-η1+c(T**-1)ζ+η)]η*G∞.

The G∞ describes the shear modulus of the completely cured material, η defines the module in the liquid state, and c and ζ are fitting parameters to experimental data. The advantage of this formulation is a more accurate but also smooth function, as the modulus can be modeled in a good agreement to experimental data (Figure 5). It is easy to adapt the model to experimental results using the lower bound, shift and rotation factors. Comparing the proposed formulation to the earlier discussed formulations (Figure 6) with respect to numerical integration schemes, the proposed formulation is also more convergence stable as the solver does not have to pass points of discontinuity as, for example, found in the formulation of Johnston.3 Figure 5.
Comparison of experimental data and a developed model of the storage shear modulus against the degree of cure. Figure 6.
Development of the storage (full line)/loss (dashed line) shear modulus during different isothermal curing conditions.

sec.title: Temperature dependency of the modulus and thermal expansion
sec.p: Thermoset polymers can behave strongly on temperature. Therefore the objective question is how the young’s modulus and the CTE of the cured resin behave with respect to temperature changes. To answer this question, a dynamic mechanical thermal analysis (DTMA) experiment has been performed using a three-point bending test setup. A squared plate with dimensions 35 mm × 10 mm × 2 mm was tested at an excitation frequency of 1 Hz using an applied heating ramp of 3 K/min from 25 to 230°C.

Figure 7 shows change of the storage modulus against temperature. It can be observed that the Young’s modulus changes nearly linear up to a temperature of 180°C. Similar results can be found in the literature.3,8 Above 180°C, the glass transition temperature is reached and the storage modulus is decreasing. The measured glass transition temperature of the DTMA results averages at about 210°C. Figure 7.
Storage modulus dependency on the temperature (four measurements), measured using dynamic mechanical thermal analysis (DTMA) setup.
The average Young’s modulus was at room temperature (RT) 3248 N/mm2 and at a temperature of 180°C 2399 N/mm2. (8)E(T)=E(0∘C)-aE·T=3500-5.9·T.
This linear approximation of the temperature dependency of the young’s modulus can be applied for a cured material below the glass transition temperature.

Similar to the investigation of the thermal dependency on the Young’s modulus, the CTE thermal behavior can be observed. For representation of the right thermally induced stresses, the CTE of the resin is a sensitive parameter. Knowledge about the type of temperature dependency and the possibility of linear or nonlinear approximation is important and has been observed using a TMA/TA instruments. A squared cured resin probe with dimensions 10 mm × 10 mm × 2 mm was placed inside the expansion setup and heated up at a ramp of 3 K/min from 40 to 220°C.

In Figure 8, the measured CTE for cured RTM6 is shown. First of all, it is visible that the CTE depends on the temperature. The CTE at RT is 53.5 e-6/K, at 120°C is 70.1 e-6/K, and at 180°C is 69.4 e-6/K. This indicates that a linear approximation does provide reliable results up to a temperature of 180°C. It was observed that by reaching the glass transition temperature the CTE increases dramatically. Figure 8.
Coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) dependency on the temperature, measured using thermomechanical analyzer (TMA) setup.

In the literature, examples published by Johnston3 and Hobbiebrunken et al.8 use linear approximations of the temperature dependency for CTE. This might be sufficient for totally cured resin (degree of cure almost one) at lower temperatures (range from RT to 170°C). Assuming that reaching the glass transition temperature has a large influence on the CTE, the following relationship is proposed (dashed line in Figure 8): (9)α(T)=α(25∘C)+aA·TΔT=5.2e-5+1.70e-5·T180.

sec.title: Thermal–mechanical behavior of the resin
sec.p:
The stress–strain behavior of resin dependent on different temperatures has been studied by Hobbiebrunken et al. experimentally. They performed tensile tests at different temperature levels: RT, 120°C, 150°C, and 180°C. Similar experiments have been performed in this work using probe geometry of 10 × 3 mm dimension, which is conforming to the DIN EN ISO norm 527-2 (Figure 9). The tensile test was done using a Zwick1474 with an applied crosshead speed of 3 mm/min. Figure 9.
Stress–strain curves measured at different temperature (room temperature [RT], 120°C, 150°C, and 180°C).

The experimental stress–strain curves show that the Young’s modulus, the yield point, and fracture depend strongly on the temperature. The resin behaves more ductile at higher temperatures. The yield stress (0.5% offset) drops from 43.9 MPa at RT to 24 MPa at the regular curing temperature of 180°C. The fracture stress behaves similarly, its value changing from 67.8 MPa at RT to 27.6 MPa at 180°C. In comparison to the dynamical mechanical analysis (DMA) experiments, a deviation of the module has been occurred which can be explained by the used test method. Normally, strain gauges are used to measure the strain during the experiment. In fact of the high temperatures, this was not possible for all experiments. Therefore, the crosshead displacement was used to evaluate the strain. This effect can be neglected because only the stress values are used in the studies later on.

To take into account this nonlinear material behavior, a temperature-dependent yield criterion and fracture criterion has to be defined. This yield criterion can be based on an excising yield criterion like v. Mises, Tresca, Drucker, Prager, and so on. In this study, the v. Mises criteria is used, but it has to be kept in mind that the v. Mises criterion neglects the hydrostatic stress state and is not applicable to ductile polymers. The RTM6 resin, however, shows brittle failure behavior at RT. Therefore the v. Mises criterion might be sufficient but can lead to an overestimation of the yield stress. The v. Mises stress is defined as follows: (10)

Using a linear shift factor (Equations (11) and (12)), a temperature-dependent yield and fracture criterion was applied.8 In comparison to the average values of yield and fracture stress, a linear dependency was found. (11)σY(T)=43.94MPa-0.099·T ∘C (12)σF(T)=67.75MPa-0.18·T ∘C .
The two criteria were used to define regions where yielding or degradation occurs: (13)σ(ɛ,T)={E(T)ɛel if σ<σY(T)<σF(T)σY+βɛpl if σY(T)<σ<σF(T)≈0 if σY(T)<σF(T)<σ .

In case of a stress state lower than the yield stress, the material behaves linearly. In case of a stress state which is higher than the yield stress but lower than the fracture stress, the material behaves by a bilinear elastic plastic approach σY + βεpl In case of a stress state which is higher than the fracture stress, degradation occurs and the stiffness will be set to nearly zero. This formulation is used as constitutive law to describe the plasticity and degradation.

sec.title: Relaxation behavior
sec.p:
One of the crucial points in the analysis of internal stress during the manufacturing process is the description of the relaxation effect. During the manufacturing process, the relaxation will be dependent on time, temperature, and degree of cure. There is no existing standardized measuring method to characterize the relaxation during curing but for cured material there are. One of common methods use forced oscillation. This method can be used by applying different types of excitation like a mechanical excitation using DMA, a temperature excitation using dynamic DSC, and an oscillating electrical field measuring the influence on the dielectric properties. A comparison between these measuring types can be found in Wenzel. In this application, a DTMA is used with the time temperature superposition (TTS) relaxation approach. A three-point bending test setup with a squared plate of dimensions 35 mm × 10 mm × 2 mm was tested in the range of 40–200°C with isothermal temperature increments of 20°C. In each temperature increment, an initial displacement of 0.1% strain was applied and the stress relaxation was recorded for 60 min. Figure 10 shows the relaxation profiles of the fully cured resin sample total time and Figure 11 shows the same profiles over decay time. Analyzing the relaxation profiles over decay time, one important effect is visible. The relaxation profiles are nearly linear shifted in the temperature range from 40 to 160°C. The relaxation profiles at 180°C and 200°C shows a faster relaxation. This effect can be explained by the impact of the glass transition temperature. In Figure 11, it was observed that the modulus changes highly near the glass transition temperature and the use of a linear temperature shift factors is questionable. Figure 10.
Relaxation module over total time. Figure 11.
Relaxation module over decay time.

Using the TTS approach, a shift factor, a reduced time, and a master curve can be obtained. The master curve can be modeled using continuous or discrete formulation. Discrete formulation like a Prony series are commonly used for viscoelastic modeling because they provide a good accuracy, but the evaluation of the needed parameters is complex. Additionally for the curing process, the relaxation behavior depends on the material state, and as explained on the glass transition temperature, therefore a continuous closed solution might be more effective because a dependency of the glass transition temperature on a parameter can be defined more easily. As a first step, a reduced time has to be obtained: (14)ξ=∫0 t1atdt.

The time–temperature shift factor at can be modeled using the defined Williams-Landel-Ferry (WLF) equation or with linear simplification. It has been shown that for cured resin a linear approach is sufficient. (15)at=0.05·T+10[∘C].

Figure 12 is showing the master curve (reference temperature of 120°C) and the relaxation profiles. Figure 12.
Relaxation profiles and master curve.

A modified stretched exponential formulation was used to model the relaxation behavior. In this case, four parameters have to be evaluated, the relaxed module E∞(T), the unrelaxed module Ea(T), the characteristic relaxation time τ, and fitting parameter b. This continuous closed approach was used instead of a discrete approach (Prony series) to have the possibility to add in further investigation a dependency on degree of cure of the relaxation.14 (16)E(ξ)=Ea(T)+(E∞(T)-Ea(T))(1-e(-(ξτ)b)). (17)

During the evaluation of parameters, a good agreement in the temperature range of 40–160°C was found, which is displayed in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Model fit of relaxation profiles in the temperature range of 40–160°C.

Above the temperature of 160°C, a good correlation was not found, in fact, there will be an influence of the glass transition temperature. This effect will be changing the material behavior and a linear temperature shift factor will be not valid anymore. Therefore the approach will be only used in the solid state. The study on the dependency of relaxation in the rubbery state is not part of this study. A possible approach was published by the author using differential form of the relaxation written incrementally as found by Zocher et al.9 and Svanberg et al.2 Using this approach, also known as instantaneous viscoelastic approach7 or pseudoelastic approach,14 the influence of strain rate effects/velocity is not taken into account. Therefore to define the stress at the actual time step, a relaxation term can be added: (18)Δσij(t)=σij(t-Δt)e(-Δtτchr) (19)σij(t)=Cijklɛtotal+Δσij(t).

Using this formulation, the characteristic relaxation time vector τchri. can be defined and evaluated from the experimental data of Figure 14 in a different way. The total relaxation amount in percentage was taken using the not relaxed module at t = 0.1 min and the relaxed module at t = 60 min for each temperature increment. Figure 14.
Percentage of relaxation after t = 60 min vs. temperature.

Figure 14 displays this percentage of relaxation over the temperature range of 40–200°C. An exponential formulation was used to describe the dependency between characteristic relaxation time and temperature in the following way: (20)T**=-0.02·T+10.212. (21)τT,p=[1(1-η1+c(T**-1)ζ+η)]τ(p). τ(p)=1000, η=0.001, c=100, ζ=2

This formulation will be used only for the solid material. In case of rubbery material, an approach is used that is based on the degree of cure and the glass transition temperature. This approach is similar to the development of the resin module. A detailed description can be found in Brauner et al.15 (22)T**=1(1-Tg-Tgg)T-Tggl) (23)τ(p)=[1(1-η1+c(T**-1)ζ+η)]η*τ∞.

sec.title: Application test case
sec.p: In the following chapter, a numerical analysis of a composite unit cell will be down to discuss the development of process-induced stress and the influence of the experimental discovered effects.

sec.title: FE model
sec.p:
The objective of the presented study is a micromechanical modeling of a fiber matrix unit cell. Typically a fabric is made of yarns, which consist of several thousand fibers and matrix unit cells. Packing models idealize the arrangement of fibers and matrix. Generally, two idealizations can be found using squared or hexagonal packing. This geometrical idealization determines the theoretical maximum fiber volume content and which is approximately 78% for squared packing and 90% for hexagonal packing. In Figure 15, a polished microsection of a composite is shown. It is obvious that a random distribution of fiber and matrix exists. In comparison of these types of packing, it was found that a squared packing structure leads to higher thermal residual stresses of around 32%. Therefore a squared idealization of the unit cell is chosen for this study. Figure 15.
Polished microsection image of a CFRP composite.

A parametric two-dimensional (2D) model of the unit cell was built using the finite element software Samcef/Mecano and the Preprocessor and Postprocessor Samcef Field. The material of the polished microsection image was used for determination of the fiber volume content experimentally using chemical methods. The fiber volume content was in average Vf = 0.602. Analyzing the image, a fiber diameter of df = 7 μm was measured, leading to an effective length of the unit cell of l = 8 μm: (24)l=rf 2πVf=8.00μ m.

Using this topology, a 2D plain strain model was built consisting of 13,938 quadrangle elements (Fig 16). The boundary conditions are applied similar to reference [8]. The left edge (A–B) is fixed in Direction 1 and the lower edge (B–C) is fixed in Direction 2. Movement of the right edge (C–D) is restricted to a uniform movement in Direction 1 using multipoint constraints. The upper edge (A–D) is constraint in the same way to move uniformly in Direction 2. The reference material used for the polished cut image has the following curing history as shown in Figure 17. During the process, the temperature was measured using a thermocouple. This temperature profile is applied as temperature boundary conditions on the FE model. The reference temperature was defined at a temperature of 36°C taken from the experiment. Figure 16.
Finte element(FE) mesh of the unit cell model. Figure 17.
Temperature boundary conditions.

sec.title: Results of the process simulation
sec.p: The results provided by the coupled thermomechanical process analysis start at first by the development of the degree of cure and the development of the glass transition temperature during the process time.

In the analysis, the cure kinetic approach of Kamal/Sourour is integrated.10 The used cure kinetic parameters have been determined by DSC experiments. The cure kinetic is implemented via a user subroutine. Figure 18 shows the development of the degree of cure which reaches a value of 0.93 at the end of the process. For the unit cell a uniform temperature was defined therefore only one result curve is shown. Similar to the degree of cure, the glass transition temperature is calculated using the DiBenedetto equation with an extension published by Dykmann.16 The development of the glass transition temperature is shown in Figure 18 with a final temperature of 193°C. Using these curves, two important process transition points can be identified: the gel point and the vitrification point. As introduced in the previous chapter, these two points are used for identification of the state of the material between liquid and viscous as well as viscous and solid. Figure 19 shows the development of the young’s modulus and the shear modulus during the curing process using Equations (6) and (7) coupled to the glass transition temperature. Figure 18.
Simulation results of glass transition temperature and degree of cure vs. time. Figure 19.
Simulation results of Young’s and shear modulus development vs. time.

Similar to the experimental results shown in Figure 5, a smooth development of the engineering properties in the viscous material state is defined. In addition to Equation (8) and the experimental results in Figure 7, the temperature dependency of the modulus is taken into account during the cooldown from the curing temperature to RT. This results in a young’s modulus of 2677 MPa and a shear modulus of 997 MPa. In the previous chapter yielding was discussed, but will be investigated later in more detail, as it leads to local variations of the modulus.

Related to the dependency of the modulus, the CTE, a chemical-induced shrinkage coefficient (CSC) can be calculated and analyzed using Figure 20. Applying Equation (9), the CTE has a value of 55.5 1/K. The dependency of the CTE on the degree of cure during the viscous material state and the dependency on the temperature during cooling down are clearly observable. Figure 20.
Simulation results of coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) and chemical-induced shrinkage coefficient (CSC) modulus development vs. time.

The local properties of the matrix can be transferred to the composite using the global displacement of the unit cell. Figure 21 shows the scalar displacement in Direction 1 measured at point C. The sum of the heatup phase, the chemical-induced shrinkage, and the thermal-induced shrinkage at cooling down lead to the resulting process-induced displacement. The contributions of the chemical- and thermal-induced shrinkages to the CTE and CSC can be derived during the different phases of the curing process and compared to analytical micromechanical equations. Figure 21.
Simulation results of scalar displacement in direction 1 vs. time.
For the CTE, the following analytical rule of mixture is available:6 (25)α22=ϕαF⊥+(1-ϕ)αM+ϕ(1-ϕ)(αM-αF∥)*EF∥νM-EMνFϕEF∥+(1-ϕ)EM=36.3*10-61/Kα22=Δll0*ΔT=(6.57-2.51)*10-58.0*10-3*(170-36)=37.8*10-61/K.

Comparison of the results from the FE analysis shows a good agreement between the analytical approach and the unit cell results. Similar to the CTE, the CSC can be compared. For the CSC, different analytical micromechanical approaches are available as published by Johnston3 and Wijskamp.7 (26)

The chemical shrinkage can be obtained from the volumetric shrinkage in association to the degree of cure p. For the given 2D application, the percentage of shrinkage can be calculated using the total area of the unit cell at points 2 and 3. The comparison shows a difference between the analytical and numerical approaches of about 48%. This leads to the result that the analytical approach for the description of a homogenized CSC is not sufficient.

sec.title: Effects of matrix nonlinearities on the formation of residual stresses
sec.p: In the experimental part of this study, it is shown that the matrix behavior is thermomechanically complex. Effects like temperature dependency on the Young’s modulus and CTE, nonlinear temperature-dependent stress–strain behavior, microyielding and viscoelastic relaxation effects will be discussed now by adding stepwise more complexity to the material law of the FE model. Therefore in this chapter, first a linear analysis is performed as reference. In this analysis, no temperature dependencies are taken into account. The material parameters are taken from Table 2. As temperature difference, the maximum process temperature (170°C) and the RT (36°C) are selected. In a second step, a transient analysis of the whole curing process is performed and the effect of cure shrinkage induced strain is added. The resin engineering properties are coupled to the degree of cure by Equations (3)–(5). In the third step, the temperature dependency of the Young’s modulus and the CTE is added to step 2 by applying Equations (8) and (9). In a fourth analysis, the nonlinear stress–strain dependency (Equations (10)–(13)) is added to the model including microyielding and microdegradation. In the fifth and last step, the material model is extended by a relaxation term.

Analyzing the results of Table 4 and Figure 22, the formation of residual stresses is given. In the first row, the equivalent v. Mises stress is shown. This criterion neglects the influence of the hydrostatic stress state and assumes that yielding is independent. Therefore the first principal stress is also shown. The v. Mises stress might be usable for duromere resin because the thermal and chemical shrinkages lead to tensile stress components. Figure 22.
Results of the parameter study on the effect of matrix nonlinearities. Table 3.
Average values
RT (25°C) 120°C 150°C 180°C
Young’s module (MPa) 1949.87 1301.23 1239.6 1035.63
Standard deviation 119.95 53.5 64.69 81.89
Yield stress (MPa) 41.74 29.23 33.17 24.32
Standard deviation 2.96 3.37 1.40 3.09
Fracture stress (MPa) 60.04 51.61 44.02 27.63
Standard deviation 3.39 2.26 3.01 2.65
RT: room temperature.
Table 4.
Results
Study 1 Study 2 Study 3 Study 4 Study 5
Thermal shrinkage Thermal + chemical shrinkage Thermal + chemical shrinkage Thermal + chemical shrinkage Thermal + chemical shrinkage
Temp.- dependent properties Temp.- dependent properties Temp.- dependent properties
Matrix yielding + degradation Matrix yielding + degradation
Stress relaxation
Max. global displacement 28.2 × 10−6 68.9 × 10−6 72.4 × 10−6 72.5 × 10−6 7.17 × 10−6
Res. global CTE 36.4 × 10−6 1/K 33.9 × 10−6 1/K 38.0 × 10−6 1/K 38.5 × 10−6 1/K 3.80 × 10−6 1/K
Max. local strain 2.92% 7.2% 7.4% 7.7% 7.3%
Max. global strain 0.48% 0.90% 0.90% 0.90% 0.89%
Max. local v. Mises stress 64.4 MPa 153MPa 134 MPa 67 MPa 67 MPa
Max. local first principal 38.8 MPa 211 MPa 182 MPa 130 MPa 72 MPa
CTE: coefficient of thermal expansion.

It is visible that the sum of thermal and chemical shrinkages lead to a higher stress state with a value of 220 MPa for the v. Mises stress (Study 2). This value reaches the yielding and failure points and displays the need to extend the material law to the effect of temperature-dependent material properties. Adding this effect (Study 3), the maximum v. Mises stress decreases slightly to 178 MPa, but the values are still very high and out of range of Hooke law. Study 4 adds the nonlinear stress–strain relation to the model (Equations (10)–(13)). The results show a significant decreasing in the residual stresses to 110 MPa. The maximum of the stress changes from a point-wise distribution to a more plane distribution. In the last step, stress relaxation is added to the model. The effect of relaxation will be faster at high temperatures than at RT, therefore the effect of chemical-induced stresses on the level of stress is smaller. In comparison to the previous study, the distribution of the v. Mises stress is more uniform.

Applying the information of temperature-dependent yielding and failure, the regions where these effects appear can be displayed. Microscopic yielding occurs at the positions of high stresses. This yielding leads to a redistribution of the stress influencing the matrix and additional yielding also in regions where the matrix behaves linear (compare Study 3) occurs. The redistribution decreases the total effort on the matrix but cannot avoid microscopic damage, which takes place close to the matrix–fiber interface. The FE model was built to analyze the inner stress state of the matrix. The physical behavior of the fiber–matrix interface was assumed to be ideally aligned. Therefore at this point, no differentiation can be found between matrix or interface failure. The Figure 23 shows the regions of yielding and failure for Study 4 (without relaxation) and Study 5 (with relaxation). It can be observed that the description of the viscoelastic effect by stress relaxation is a sensitive parameter on the maximal amount of stress and process defects. The DMA experiment has shown that the effect of relaxation on cured resin samples is important. Additionally, it was shown that a linear viscoelastic approach is not sufficiently close to the glass transition temperature. Taking a critical view on the numerical results, it is obvious that the idealization of linear viscoelasticity is insufficient. In Figure 23 the regions of yielding are displayed. Coming from the geometry of fiber and matrix, an effect like notch stress appears. The increase will be affected in a way that a linear viscoelastic approach cannot be used. This leads to the conclusion that the effect of viscoelasticity is not thermorheological simple and more thermorheological complex due to the two effects, softening close to the glass transition temperature and yielding/failure in fact of high stress values. Figure 23.
Results of Studies 4 and 5 – matrix yielding and failure.

sec.title: Effects of microresidual stress/defects on the macrolevel
sec.p: The previous study has demonstrated that combined chemical and thermal shrinkage during manufacturing can lead to high microstress levels and to defects like microyielding, microdegradation and fiber–matrix interface failure. The sum of these effects will influence the resulting properties of the composite. In general, residual stresses will increase strength and stiffness because their nature is of type tensile and external loads have the opposite direction. Defects will decrease stiffness and strength properties because they are the starting points of failure in case of external loading. Therefore the transfer of the results on the microlevel can be an important method to validate the stiffness, stress level, and strength on the macroscale. The transfer between microscale and macroscale is usually done by analytical or numerical homogenization methods. One of the simplest homogenization methods is to use the numerical model and to apply after the process simulation, a mechanical analysis of a tensile test. Using a displacement function, the total reaction force can be calculated and macrostiffness and stress can derivate taking into account the geometrical dimension of the unit cell.

A linear displacement function is applied on side A–B in negative Direction 1 with the value of 1% macrostrain. The side D–C is able to move during process simulation and fixed using fixation in the tensile test. The total reaction force which will be used to calculate the strength and macrostress is the sum of forces taking node values of side D–C in Direction 1. In the Figure 24, the stress–strain relation of the macrolevel is shown. It is visible that the macroresponse is not linear and a damage accumulation starts at a strain value of 0.7% and decreases the stiffness. Figure 24.
Macro stress–strain relation.

The damage distribution can be shown using the damage variable (Figure 25) at discrete points. It is visible that the failure starts from the initial process defect/damage and grows taking a 45°angle from one fiber to another. In case of residual stress-free configuration, a failure would occur between the upper and lower fibers first. In case of this configuration with process-induced stresses, the failure behavior changes and the damage grows in the opposite direction. Figure 25.
Development of matrix damage for macro strain value of 0.8, 1.1, 1.3, and 2.2%. The nature of the residual stress is tensile. Therefore the mechanical load has the opposite direction. The Figure 26 shows this stress state schematically using black arrows for mechanical-induced stresses and red arrows for process-induced stresses.
The conclusion can be found that high process-induced stresses change the failure behavior on the microscale dramatically.

In the following parameter study, the results of the analysis will be compared to three different stress configurations without residual stresses and with three different residual stress configurations (thermal, thermal + chemical, and thermal + chemical + nonlinear effects).

It can be observed that the residual stress states have a large influence on the stiffness values. In case of residual stress-free configuration, the Young’s modulus will be 14733 MPa. Adding only thermal-induced stresses, the stiffness increase due to the effect descript in Figure 26 leads to a value of 19361 MPa. In case of using the total sum from thermal- and chemical-induced shrinkage stresses, the stiffness decreases to a value of 9539 MPa. For the observed material (RTM6/G1157), the following reference values can be taken from the datasheet.17 Therefore the following properties are available, transverse module at RT = 9400 MPa (standard deviation 200 MPa) and transverse tensile strength = 67 MPa (standard deviation 9 MPa). In comparison to these experimentally evaluated values, the numerical results show a good correlation. Figure 26.
Stress state schematically black arrows for mechanical-induced stress, red arrows for process-induced stresses. Figure 27.
Influence of different residual stress states on macrostiffness.

Using this parameter study, it was possible to show the effect of process-induced stresses on macrostiffness and their influence on material strength. It is possible to use the nonlinear approach including effects like plasticity, degradation, and relaxation to make a prediction for the material strength and to predict the material stiffness with a higher accuracy.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
In the presented study, process-dependent residual stresses of composite materials have been analyzed using a process simulation of a squared unit cell including thermal- and chemical-induced shrinkage. Experiments show that the polymer matrix behaves nonlinear. Temperature-dependent effects like yielding, fracture, and relaxation have been added to the FE model stepwise. The following results are found:
Analyzing process-dependent residual stresses only using temperature gradients is not sufficient and leads to wrong maximum stress values and wrong stress distributions.
Adding chemical shrinkage to thermal shrinkage leads to unrealistically high stress values in case of linear matrix behavior. In reality, the polymer behaves thermomechanically complex and yielding and degradation occurs. After matrix yielding, a redistribution of stress takes place leading to a more uniform stress distribution.
During the process degradation and damage appear in the fiber–matrix interface. This degrades the resulting composite strength.

The process-dependent stress and defects have been afterwards used and studied to identify their effect on the macroscale. The following conclusion can been found:
The failure behavior changes in case of a superposition with mechanical tensile load. The process-induced stresses change the points of maximum stress.
The stiffness is influenced by the process-induced stress.

Altogether, these developments and their complete integration within commercially available software packages, like MECANO/SAMCEF, can provide engineers an advanced analysis and simulation tool to compute process-induced deformations and residual stresses. It has been shown that process-induced stress based on thermal- and chemical-induced shrinkage can be analyzed using a micromechanical model with reliable results. The application of this could be a more accurate approach to compute homogenized engineering properties, strength, and residual stresses.

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
